roleset.name: put into order
roleset.note: SORT-V NOTES: Based on sentences in wsj. Member of VNcls classify-29.10. (from sort.01-v)

example.name: all args
example.text: [The new machines]-1 are capable of *trace*-1 sorting by zip code up to 10,000 large flat mail pieces, including magazines and parcels, an hour.
example.arg: up to 10,000 large flat mail pieces, including magazines and parcels, an hour

example.name: sort through
example.text: [Most companies]-1 still are trying *trace*-1 to sort through the wreckage caused by Hurricane Hugo in the Carolinas last month.
example.arg: through the wreckage caused by Hurricane Hugo in the Carolinas last month

roleset.name: make sense of, distinguish
roleset.note: SORT_OUT-V NOTES: Member of VNcls classify-29.10. (from sort.02-v)

example.name: make sense of
example.text: That process of *trace* sorting out specifics is likely to take time, the Japanese say, no matter how badly the U.S. wants quick results.

example.name: this from that
example.text: Without a microscope and a subpoena, it's often hard *trace* to sort out worthwhile causes from ripoffs if all you've got to go on is the solicitation itself.

example.name: this and that merged
example.text: ``All these interconnected computers make it difficult *trace* to sort out what's junk and what's important,'' says Chuck Digate, a former Lotus Development executive who has started a new company to cope with the problem.
